tn.ref: what was evil in the sight of Yahweh
tn.text: Here "in the sight of Yahweh" represents what Yahweh considers or thinks about something. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jdg:02:11|2:11]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Here "Midian" represents the people of Midian. Also, "hand" represents control. AT: "the control of the people of Midian" or "the control of the Midianites" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: The power of Midian oppressed Israel
tn.text: Here "the power of Midian" refers to the people of Midian. AT: "The people of Midian were more powerful than the people of Israel and they oppressed them"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
places in the rocky cliffs that would provide shelter

tn.ref: They would set up their army
tn.text: "The army would encamp" or "The army would set up their tents"

tn.ref: Whenever they and their livestock and tents came up
tn.text: The land of Midian was south of the land of Israel, near the Red Sea. It was common to use the phrase "came up" when speaking of traveling from Midian to Israel. AT: "Whenever the Midianites brought their livestock and tents to the land of Israel"

tn.ref: they would come as a swarm of locusts
tn.text: The Midianites are compared to a swarm of locusts because they came in with a great number of people and their livestock ate everything that grew. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
This is an exaggeration, a hyperbole, showing the number is very great. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
Here "Midian" represents the people of Midian. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is an idiom. AT: "prayed to Yahweh for help" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom. AT: "prayed to Yahweh for help" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "Midian" represents the people of Midian. AT: "because of the Midianites" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: I brought you up from Egypt
tn.text: "I led you out of Egypt"
Moses speaks of Egypt as if it were a house where people keep slaves. AT: "the place where you were slaves" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
In this phrase "hand" represents power or control. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
- Here "my voice" represents what Yahweh commanded. AT: "obeyed my command" or "obeyed me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This word is used here to mark a break in the storyline. Here the narrator starts to tell a new part of the story.
In 6:11-24 Yahweh appears to Gideon in the form of an angel. AT: "Yahweh, who appeared as an angel," or "Yahweh"
This is the name of a town. (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is a people group named after their ancestor Abiezer. (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: was separating out the wheat by beating it on the floor
tn.text: This is a process called "threshing." Gideon was beating the wheat against the floor to separate the wheat grain from the rest of the wheat plant.
"went to him"
Gideon uses the word "master" as a polite way to greet a stranger. He does not realize he is speaking to Yahweh in the form of an angel or a man.

tn.ref: Where are all his wonderful deeds that our fathers told us about, when they said, 'Did not Yahweh bring us up from Egypt?'
tn.text: Gideon uses a question to challenge the stranger's statement that Yahweh was with him. Also, the direct quotation can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT:  "We have not seen any wonderful deeds like the ones our fathers told us about when Yahweh brought them up from Egypt." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])

tn.ref: gave us into the hand of Midian
tn.text: The phrase "gave us into" means Yahweh allowed the Israelites to be defeated. AT: "allowed the Midianites to defeat us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "hand" represents power or control. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "Midian" represents the people of Midian. AT: "of the Midianites" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"Yahweh looked at Gideon"
Here "hand" represents power or control. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "Midian" represents the people of Midian. AT: "of the Midianites" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Yahweh uses a question to ensure Gideon that he is sending him. Here "sent" means Yahweh has appointed Gideon with a specific task. AT: "I, Yahweh, am sending you!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Gideon now calls the person "Lord" instead of "my master" as in [[:en:bible:notes:jdg:06:13|6:13]]. Here it seems Gideon either knows or suspects that he is speaking with Yahweh.
Gideon uses a question to emphasize that he does not think he can rescue the Israelites. AT: "I cannot possibly rescue the Israelites!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"Please understand" or "Listen"
"in the tribe of Manasseh"
Here "house" represents a family. AT: "in my father's family" or "in my family" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "be with you" is an idiom that means Yahweh will help and bless Gideon. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
You can state the full meaning explicitly. AT: "as easily as if you were fighting only one man" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"place it in front of you"
If it is necessary to use a modern measurement; here is one way of doing it. AT: "with 22 liters of flour" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bvolume]])
water that has had food, such as meat, cooked in it

tn.ref: seen the angel of Yahweh face to face
tn.text: This phrase refers to two people being close to each other. AT: "really seen the angel of Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Apparently Yahweh spoke to Gideon from heaven. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This means to the time when the book of Judges was written.

tn.ref: on the top of this place of refuge
tn.text: The city of Ophrah was on top of a hill. Israelites fled there for refuge from the Midianites.
"place the stones in an orderly manner" or "and build it properly"

tn.ref: did as Yahweh had told him
tn.text: This refers to Yahweh's command in [[:en:bible:notes:jdg:06:25|6:25-26]].
"got up out of bed" or "woke up"

tn.ref: the altar of Baal was broken down, and the Asherah that was beside it was cut down, and the second bull had been offered on the altar that had been built
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "they noticed that someone had broken down the altar of Baal, cut down the Asherah that was beside it, and built an altar and sacrificed the second bull on it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: he may be put to death
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "we may kill him as punishment" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Will you plead the case for Baal?
tn.text: Joash uses a question to emphasize that a human should not have to defend a god. AT: "You should not have to defend Baal." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"make a defense" or "give an excuse"

This is another name for Gideon. It means "let Baal defend himself." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

The words "to battle" are understood. AT: "so they might follow him to battle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: and they too, were called out to follow him
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "calling them out to follow him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
These all represent the people of each tribe. AT: "to the tribes of Asher, Zebulun, and Naphtali" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: then I will know that you will
tn.text: The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. AT: "this will be a sign from you, and then I will know that you will" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
